loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 44 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past six years, Charles has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells essential goods like sugar, salt and water. 

To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of UGX 2,000,000 from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items to sell, such as sugar, rice and all types of flour and will help Charles to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Charles hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the shop into a wholesale shop. 

Charles is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Charles who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase for more items to sell, like sugar, rice and all types of flour.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es: La venta de recarga a celulares, dirigida a negocios es hoy la actividad generadora de ingresos de Elizabeth  y de su esposo, quien trabaja como coordinador de una empresa que comercializa este tipo de productos. Elizabeth trabaja desde su casa, donde puede efectuar las actividades que le demanda el hogar obteniendo buenos ingresos. Sus ventas que van desde cincuenta mil pesos colombianos, las realiza de contado trasladándose en una motocicleta, cuando es necesario llegar a su clientela en los mismos puntos de ventas. También en su negocio ofrece el servicio de impresiones, escanear e internet, en las que el consumidor encuentra soluciones a sus necesidades, intereses.  Su iniciativa de negocio tiene 3 años y sus sueños son cada vez mas grandes.  En la actualidad está ahorrando para adquirir su propia casa  aunque tiene como meta a corto plazo tener un café internet que complemente su negocio en varios puntos de la ciudad . En la actualidad se ha acercado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, pues esta aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a esta organización mediante el cual comprará un alto volumen de recargas a celulares, para continuar extendiendo su marco de mercado y e incrementar la oferta de servicios de impresiones y escaner impactando esta inversión de manera positiva en su negocio.
texts.en:
Elizabeth and her husband earn their income selling cell phone minutes (recharges) directed to businesses, working as a coordinator of a business that sells this type of products. Elizabeth works from home, where she can perform needed household activities earning a good income.

Her sales range from fifty thousand Colombian pesos. She does them traveling on a motorcycle when she needs to reach her customers at the same points of sales. Her business also offers printing service, scanning and internet, in which the customer finds solutions to their needs and interests. 

Her business initiative is three years old and her dreams are getting bigger. Currently she is saving to buy her own home, but she has a short-term goal to have an internet cafe that complements her business in various parts of the city. 

At present she has approached the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, because she's applying for a Kiva loan: the first financing this organization does. Through this, she will buy a high volume of cell phone minute recharges to continue expanding her market and increase printing and scanning services. This investment will impact her business in a positive manner.

loans.use: to buy a large volume of cell phone minutes (recharges).

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en: This is 46 year-old Kadiatu. She is married and has three children, ages 15,18, and 24. She has one additional dependent living with her. In 2001, Kadiatu established her gari (ground cassava) business. She began her business because she was not educated. .Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Kadiatu has already received and successfully repaid her first loan, and now requires this new loan to buy more gari. In the future, Kadiatu plans to assist her husband to educate their children. She is hard working and thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more gari (ground cassava).

loans.name: Jenneth

texts.en:
Jenneth, 50, is a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo, a driver, and they have five children. One child is in college, two are in high school, one is in the elementary level and the other one is already working. She manages her household while operating the business.  She works hard to earn income to support and meet the family's daily personal and household needs and to send her four children to school.

Jenneth operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg.  She earns a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  Aside from this business, she also has a tricycle unit for transport service which her husband drives to earn additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of PHP 1,000 a day.

To help her continue operation of her variety store business, she is requesting a PHP 43,000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as fresh meat, sacks of rice, charcoal, and soda. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Jenneth hopes to maintain and grow her business so her family could have a better life. She strives hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay  Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Tuda Group

texts.en:
Rashidi is 36 years old, married, and has four children, three school-aged and one still a baby. For three years now, he has had a business making and selling furniture. Rashidi started his enterprise just as a normal carpenter, selling beds and chairs on order, but he is now able to sell more furniture and of different types to passing customers. This was possible because of Kiva's support. A painting machine and enough stock of wood are the greatest challenges facing his enterprise. 

Rashidi starts his business at 7;30 am and works till 8:00 pm daily and is able to make a good profit each month.

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is his second loan request to be apportioned among Tuda's two group members. The group members will hold each other accountable to repay the loan. Rashidi will use his credit request to replenish his business with wood for making furniture. 

Rashid used the previous loan to buy a color spray machine which he uses now to color his furniture to make it look attractive. He is so happy because he is now able to receive more orders than before. He managed to earn extra income which he used to cover school fees and household expenses. In the coming years, he would like to grow his business and be better-off in life.

loans.use: to replenish his business with wood for making furniture.

loans.name: Ika Ithano Farmers Self Help Group

texts.en:
In 2012, Ika Ithano Farmers Self Help Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in order to be trained in financial management, enterprise development, and savings management to help improve their livelihoods. The members in this group are mostly involved in farming activities.

The person raising her hand is Mary. She is 47 years old and married. She lives with her husband and has three children. She farms kale and maize, and also does dairy farming. She has applied for a loan to buy certified seeds to help improve her crop yield. She hopes for a bounty harvest and more income. This will enable her to cater to her family's needs.

All members in this group are very happy with this loan and are grateful to Kiva and their lenders for their help and support.

loans.use: To buy certified seeds to improve her crop yield.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en: Clementine is 44 years old. She is married and has two children between 9 and 18 years of age.  Both of her children attend school. She has a butcher shop and has been working in this business for the past 10 years. With this loan, she would like to buy more cows to butcher for meat to sell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest in the business and to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Mwanafaki

texts.en:
Mwanafaki is married and has four children who attend school. she owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

For the past three years, she has operated a business renting houses, with her potential customers being tenants. Her major challenge is seasonality in the business.

With the 50,000 KES she wants to furnish her house by painting her rental house. she decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to furnish her house by painting her rental house

loans.name: Miosotis

texts.en:
Miosotis came to the US from the Dominican Republic where she grew up and studied Business Law. She realized she could help out other immigrants with her translation skills. “My greatest accomplishment is being able to provide people with help in acquiring papers to work and support their families,” she says.  Miosotis is in Hamilton, NJ with her children.

Miosotis works out of her home and is seeking a loan to buy a projector, desk, and chairs to create an office space.  Developing this formal workspace will enable her to better service her clients and lay an important foundation for future growth.

loans.use: to pay for office furniture

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan, 56, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Ramon, a businessman, and is the mother to her children. She manages their household, together with her husband and children, while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Susan operates a food processing business. She makes homemade pastries and she specializes in pizza. She earns an income by selling her products to her neighbors and to suppliers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy raw ingredients and materials needed to expand her product inventory.

Susan dreams of having a transportation service like a tricycle, which she could also use for business purposes and to help with their everyday expenses. She hopes that her house will also be renovated someday. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Mupa

texts.en:
Mupa is married and has five children who still attend school. This is the reason for her hard work.  She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Mupa cooks and sells food in a hotel for the past one year, and also sells to passersby and neighbors. She is asking for this loan to buy tomatoes, onions, chicken, rice, cooking oil and other products to stock her food cooking business and have good products to offer to her customers. She is grateful for this opportunity she’s getting that will help her very much. She really appreciates the loan granted to her previously.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions, chicken, rice, cooking oil and other products

loans.name: Delphine

texts.en: Delphine is 37 years old. She is married and has four children who range in age from 8 to 16 years. All of her children attend school. She sells clothes and has been running a business for the past two years. With the loan, she would like to buy more clothes for resale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Bambi

texts.en:
This is Bambi, 27, a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Richard, a tricycle driver, and is the mother to their three children. Their first child is still in the preparatory school and the other two are not of school age yet. She and her husband work hard to meet their everyday needs and to support their child’s schooling. 

Bambi operates a tricycle unit, which her husband drives. The tricycle carries up to four passengers. In the Philippines, especially in the provinces like Palawan, tricycles are a common means of transportation. Jeepneys and buses are limited. Very few people own a vehicle. The town people usually ride a tricycle from their homes to market, to church, to their friends' homes and to other destinations within their community. They even ride from one town to another. Bambi earns a minimum of 700 PHP a day.

Bambi, like many other Filipinas, is a very industrious woman, so she is opening a general store. For additional working capital she is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy grocery items such as rice, charcoal, cooking oil, and canned goods. She is confident that her store will have a good return since it will have all the essential food items that any household needs every day. She thanks God and you in advance and is grateful for the financial help that will be given to her. This will definitely help meet her family's daily expenses and send her children to school. 

Bambi dreams of being successful in her two businesses so she can give her children the best education possible and a better future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To open a general store and buy grocery items.

loans.name: Mnyazi

texts.en:
Mnyazi  is widowed and has eight children; three are in school and the rest are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase fishing nets for her fish selling business at the local market. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is grateful for the previous loan given to her.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets for her business

loans.name: Paz Del Carmen

texts.es:
Paz tiene 35 años de edad, tiene noveno grado de nivel académico, está acompañada y su pareja se dedica al comercio, en esta relación han procreado 3 hijos los cuales dos de ellos están en la escuela y el otro aún no asiste porque está pequeño.

Paz se dedica a atender un molino junto con su hermana, ya tiene tres años de estar ayudándole, también Paz tiene una pequeña tienda y aprovecha de vender cuando las personas llegan a moler al lugar.

Ella necesita este crédito para comprar más productos y surtir  la tienda, comprará frijoles, arroz, aceite, huevos, tomates, cebolla y todo lo que se utiliza para la alimentación en los hogares .

Los sueños de Paz tener una tienda más fuerte y un molino propio ya que en la comunidad se va poblando de más personas y por lo tanto podrían ser clientes potenciales.
texts.en:
35-year old Paz has a grade 9 education. She is married to a businessman, and they have three children, two of whom attend school. The third one is still to young to go to school. To earn their living, Paz and her sister have been running a mill for three years. Paz also has a small store which is used by the people who come to grind their corn.

She needs a loan to buy more products for her store. She wishes to buy beans, rice, oil, eggs, tomatoes, onions, and anything else that people buy to eat in their homes.

Her dreams are to have a better store and a mill of her own since she sees her community growing, resulting in potential new customers.

loans.use: buy beans, rice, oil, eggs, tomatoes, onions etc.

loans.name: Kakiika Twetungure Group

texts.en:
Kakika Group is an old group located in Kakika Kajara Ntungamo district, it’s comprised of women and men whose major activities are retail businesses and others are engaged in agriculture They applied for loan of 2,500,000. They divided this money among themselves. They have a challenge of low production within their farming  and retail businesses due to poor farming methods and price fluctuation. Their prime target is to yield high output from their plantations and have much stock in their business, also to take their children to better schools. They are limited by capital and funds to enable them achieve their dreams. With the financial boost from Kiva through UGAFODE, they will shortly be on the road to success. 

Annet will use her loan to buy dry grass for mulch and drug cow dug that she will spread in her banana plantation to make a difference in the yields. The 8th person on the extreme left is the UGAFODE credit officer.

loans.use: To buy organic fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Dimanche

texts.en: This loan helps Dimanche get connected to his local prepay microgrid. Dimanche is a farmer and lives with his wife and his six kids in the town of Les Anglais in southern Haiti. Their white wooden house has no reliable access to electricity, and thus, Dimanche is forced to use costly and harmful kerosene for lighting. With three of his kids still at school, he wishes they had better light for studying at night. A solar-powered microgrid is being installed in Les Anglais, giving Dimanche and his family the opportunity to connect to a higher quality, lower-cost energy source. He is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to cover the upfront cost of connection to the grid, which he will repay through his payments for electricity. An electrical connection dramatically reduces the cost of lighting in towns such as Les Anglais while offering far superior light quality, and more generally, providing opportunities for people to dramatically improve their quality of life. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Inosnese

texts.en: This loan helps Inosnese get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Inosnese is a 27-year-old mother, and her only kid is going to school. She runs a small business and lives in a small brown and green wooden house in Les Anglais, in southern Haiti. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to get reliable electricity at home. After running pilots since 2012 that proved the benefits of prepay quality electricity to people in Les Anglais (first with 14 households, and then up to 54), EarthSpark International is developing a full-scale, solar-powered microgrid. This micro-grid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households. Kiva loans allow EarthSpark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the up-front costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Guerline

texts.en: This loan helps Guerline get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Guerline is a 26-year-old mother, and her only kid is going to school. She lives in a small green wooden house in Les Anglais, in southern Haiti. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to finally get rid of her dirty, costly kerosene lamp. After running pilots since 2012 that proved the benefits of prepay quality electricity to people in Les Anglais (first with 14 households, and then up to 54), EarthSpark International is developing a full-scale, solar-powered microgrid. This microgrid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households. Kiva loans allow EarthSpark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the up-front costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Junette

texts.en: This loan helps Junette get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Junette runs a small business and lives with her husband and her two kids in the town of Les Anglais in southern Haiti. Their blue and yellow house has no reliable access to electricity and thus Junette is forced to use costly and harmful kerosene for lighting. She wishes her kids had better light for studying at night. A solar-powered microgrid is being installed in Les Anglais, giving Junette and her family the opportunity to connect to a higher quality, lower-cost energy source. She is looking forward to being connected as it will allow her to save money. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to cover the upfront cost of connection to the grid, which she will repay through her payments for electricity. An electrical connection dramatically reduces the cost of lighting in towns such as Les Anglais while offering far superior light quality and more generally providing opportunities for people to dramatically improve their quality of life. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Shalom Self Help Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Jedida. She is a member of Shalom Self Help Group. She is 63 years old and a mother of five.  

She does mixed farming that includes growing maize and beans and poultry and dairy farming. She has learned to effectively manage the farming activities after the enterprise training she got from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa. Jedida would like to borrow through Kiva to further expand her poultry business by buying more chickens, since there is a lot of demand for poultry meat and eggs. She anticipates an increased income; hence she will be able to maintain a consistent food supply in her household.

She is grateful for the Kiva loan and promises to repay it promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Rosner

texts.en: This loan helps Rosner get connected to his local prepay microgrid. Rosner is a farmer and lives with his wife and 6 kids in the town of Les Anglais in southern Haiti. Their brown and green wooden house has no reliable access to electricity and Rosner is forced to use costly and harmful kerosene for lighting. A solar-powered microgrid is being installed in Les Anglais, giving Rosner and his family the opportunity to connect to a higher quality, lower-cost energy source. He worries that regular kerosene use is harming his and his family’s long-term health. He is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to cover the upfront cost of connection to the grid, which he will repay through his payments for electricity. An electrical connection dramatically reduces the cost of lighting in towns such as Les Anglais while offering far superior light quality and more generally providing opportunities for people to dramatically improve their quality of life. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Roselore

texts.en: This loan helps Roselore get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Roselore lives in the town of Les Anglais in southern Haiti. Her green wooden house has no reliable access to electricity, and thus, Roselore is forced to use costly and harmful kerosene for lighting. A solar-powered microgrid is being installed in Les Anglais, giving Roselore the opportunity to connect to a higher quality, lower-cost energy source. She is looking forward to being connected, as it will allow her to save money. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to cover the upfront cost of connection to the grid, which she will repay through her payments for electricity. An electrical connection dramatically reduces the cost of lighting in towns such as Les Anglais, while offering far superior light quality, and more generally, providing opportunities for people to dramatically improve their quality of life. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Lucelle

texts.en:
Lucelle is shown at the center of the photo surrounded by her customers. She is a 23-year-old resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Lucelle is a soft-drinks dealer. She buys large quantities of soft drinks from a soft-drinks factory and then sells them to different variety stores. Her ability to please people gives her an increasing number of loyal customers. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 17,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy more stock of soft drinks varieties to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Lucelle hopes to become a successful businesswoman someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and  also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of soft-drinks needed in her business.

loans.name: Usuf

texts.en:
This is 32 year-old Usuf. He is married and has two children who are 14 and 13 years old. He has no additional dependents. In 2009, Usuf established his commercial bike riding business. He began his business because after the death of his parents, he decided to go into bike riding.

Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 6,000,000. Usuf has already received and successfully repaid his first loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy another bike. In the future, Usuf plans to buy a vehicle as personal transport. The major challenge is the health outbreak in the country. He is hardworking, and he thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more bikes to loan.

loans.name: Nyawa

texts.en:
Nyawa is married with seven children. She buys, packages, and sell hardwood charcoal. At first, she used to buy the charcoal already packaged, but she was able to expand her storage area and she can now store up to 60,000 kg of charcoal. She buys bags and polyurethane, packages the charcoal, and sells it to small businesses in the zone. 

She needs this loan to buy charcoal because she is increasing her number of customers and needs to increase her amount of charcoal to meet their demands. Her greatest desire is to provide an education for her seven children who attend school so that she can guarantee them a prosperous future.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Heremaniya

texts.en:
Heremaniya is 35 years old, he is married with 3 children aged between 10 and 16, all of them go to school. He has been farming for 18 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain undeserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers.

loans.name: Penninah

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Penninah who is twenty-nine years old, married, and a mother of one child. 

In the year 2013 she joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in order to benefit from its training for savings mobilization, enterprise creation, and financial management. 

She runs a green grocer kiosk where she sells fruits and vegetables. She is taking a loan to expand her business by adding more stock of fruit such as mangoes, bananas, oranges, and pawpaws. She will be in a position to meet her customers rising demands and, hence, make more income. This will help support her family by ensuring food security in their household. 

She is very grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the continued support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fruit such as mangoes, bananas, pawpaw, and oranges.

loans.name: Asaph

texts.en:
Asaph is a permanent resident of Rugando, Rwampara in the Mbarara district. He is married with 8 children and 4 dependents from his brother who died 5 years ago. He grew up with only his mother, as his father died when he was still a young boy which made his life difficult. Being pushed by the need to survive and to support his mother, he started banana farming on a small scale on the land he got from his grandfather. This banana plantation was used as a source of food for the family and income for their survival. 

Asaph is a hardworking man who has managed to start other businesses like poultry. These businesses have grown, giving him an opportunity to support his family and dependants. He has also managed to construct a house for his family. 

He is requesting a loan of UGX 3,500,000 to complete his house.

loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Savannah Academy Group

texts.en:
This is a group of primary school teachers in a school in Nairobi within Tassia estate, a middle income area. They are in their early 30's and they all use charcoal for cooking. With traditional cook stoves, there is a lot of indoor air pollution which leads to respiratory diseases and also there is a lot of charcoal consumption by the traditional stoves.

Currently, on average, each member spends USD 1.3 on charcoal everyday. The loan will enable them purchase high efficient cook stoves Jikokoa that will save them up to 50% of their daily consumption on charcoal. These cook stoves also reduce smoke and carbon emissions from the charcoal thus creating a better and cleaner environment for their families.

The families will be able to save USD 0.65 daily from the reduced consumption on charcoal. This translates to USD 234 every year for at least 5 years (lifetime of the cook stove). This money will be saved and used for other needs like paying for their children's school fees, paying rent and making their lives better.

loans.use: to purchase an improved high-efficiency cook stove.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is married and all her children are grown and are living on their own. 

She is requesting a loan of GHS 1,500 to buy additional supplies for her business, including smoked fish. She has been doing business for 21 years and started this business with the help of her husband. 

She's taking a loan from ID-Ghana to increase her income as she wants to do this business for a very long time. She is happy with the loan that was offered by ID-Ghana for her to have more working capital to buy more firewood and fish to smoke and sell to customers. 

She promises to repay it without trouble. This is her 10th loan cycle.

loans.use: to buy more firewood and fish to smoke and sell to customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, oils, roots, vegetables, chicken, fish and refreshments in greater volume.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is a very hard-working entrepreneur from Coron, Palawan. She is 50 years old and has children. Her husband is Roberto and she manages a buy-and-sell business. Her income from the business is helping with their everyday needs and expenses.

What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and then sells it piecemeal at a little profit. Products can range from ready-to-wear clothing and eye wear to beads, bracelets and other similar products. She also sells rice, which she buys by the sack, and other goods. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 800 PHP in sales every day.

Emma is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan to purchase more products and merchandise to sell. She will use her loan to improve her sales. The additional revenue will help improve the general living conditions of her family.

In the future, Emma hopes to grow and expand her business. She dreams of a happy and better living for her family and she also desires that her youngest child finish schooling. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy varieties of merchandise necessary to increase her product inventory.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en: Rolando is an artisan from Guatemala who specializes in wood sculptures and jewelry. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of wood. Rolando has been selling through NOVICA since 2012. This is his story: "My brothers and I raised corn but I have a bad leg that didn't let me move easily through the fields. Although farming is our family legacy, I began making furniture at home to sell. One day in 1988 I began carving a piece of wood out of curiosity. I realized I was good at it! What a blessing! I never imagined I'd become an artisan, but discovering the beautiful world of handicrafts has been a great gift of God. "Thanks for this microcredit. Working so far from the city means that our costs are higher, especially during peak season. This loan will allow me to purchase in bulk and obtain a much better price." Use the link below to view Rolando's wood sculptures and jewelry on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/8411

loans.use: to invest in a bulk purchase of wood for his wood sculptures and jewelry

loans.name: Young Stage School Group

texts.en:
This is a group of 3 primary school teachers in a school in Nairobi within Huruma slum. Their school is made of iron sheet and is dilapidated. They are in their late 20's and they all use charcoal for cooking. With traditional cook stoves, there is a lot of indoor air pollution which leads to respiratory diseases and also there is a lot of charcoal consumption by the traditional stoves.

Currently on average each member spends USD 1.3 on charcoal everyday. The loan will enable them purchase highly efficient cook stoves Jikokoa that will save them up to 50% of their daily consumption on charcoal. These cook stoves also reduce smoke and carbon emissions from the charcoal thus creating a better and cleaner environment for their families.

The families will be able to save USD 0.65 daily from the reduced consumption on charcoal. This translates to USD 234 every year for at least 5 years (lifetime of the cook stove). They want to use the money they save to work on rebuilding the classrooms and hopefully buy solar lanterns to use for lighting.

loans.use: to purchase an improved high-efficiency cookstove

loans.name: School Group

texts.en:
This is a group of teachers in a school in Nairobi within Harambee Estate. They all want to channel the savings they get from using the improved cookstove towards their pension savings. They are aged between 35 and 50 years and they all use charcoal for cooking. With traditional cook stoves, there is a lot of Indoor Air Pollution (IAP)which leads to respiratory diseases and also there is a lot of charcoal consumption by the traditional stoves.

Currently on average each member spends USD1.3 on charcoal everyday. The loan will enable them purchase high efficient cook stoves- JIKOKOA that will save them up to 50% of their daily consumption on charcoal. These cook stoves also reduce smoke and carbon emissions from the charcoal thus creating a better and cleaner environment for their families.

The families will be able to save USD 0.65 daily from the reduced consumption on charcoal.  This translates to USD234 every year for at least 5 years (lifetime of the cook stove).

loans.use: The borrower will use this loan to pay for an energy saving high efficient cook stove

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
This is Jane. She is a small scale farmer undertaking dairy farming. She has no other source of income. 

Jane wishes to be a big dairy farmer but has a challenge of raising adequate capital for the venture. She has two dairy cows producing 20 litres of milk per day. Her dairy activity has helped her educate her children and open a small retail shop. With a loan from Kiva, she is now poised to increase her milk production to 40 litres per day by purchasing another dairy cow. Jane is banking on Kiva for support of growing her dairy enterprise to a big enviable business she envisages.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena, 40, is a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Nolan, a tricycle driver, and has three children. One is in high school and the other two are not of school age yet. She manages her household while operating a business. She works hard to earn income to support and meet their daily personal, household needs and to send her children to school. 

Nena operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this she also has a tricycle unit for transport service which her husband drives for added income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of PHP 1000 a day. 

To help her continue operation of her general store business, Nena is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as, sacks of rice, charcoal and soda. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. Her earnings meet her family's daily expenses and  send her children to school. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Nena hopes to maintain and grow her business so she they could have a better life. She strives to hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pray for grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
This is Edward. He is a farmer in Kiambu Kenya where he has been practicing farming for the last three years. He also undertakes small scale coffee and banana farming. He currently has only one dairy cow producing a meager 6 litres of milk per day. His farm activities contribute only 60% of the required family income and he works as a driver to supplement this income.

Edward is confident that the farm activities are able to provide adequate income and is planning to resign from the driving job to concentrate on the farm activities. With a loan from Kiva, he plans to buy a dairy cow that can produce 15 litres of milk per day. A milk production of 23 litres per day will help Edward raise enough money to take good care of his family.

loans.use: to buy a second dairy cow

loans.name: Selinah

texts.en:
This is Selinah. She is a single lady from Nakuru county, Kenya. Pushed by the need to support her family, she started the business of selling potatoes in the year 2010 along the Nairobi/Uganda Road. The business is quite strenuous as she has to compete for motorist customers with the other sellers. She wishes to raise enough capital in order to establish a wholesale store and be a large scale supplier of potatoes in the region. 

With a loan from Kiva, Selinah will purchase more stock for her business. By growing her business, she comes a step closer to the wholesale business of her dream.

loans.use: to pay for more stock of potatoes for sale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
This is Jane. She is a small scale dairy farmer in Kericho, Kenya. She is a mother of four children and has been farming for the last 25 years. She enjoys dairy farming because it affords her regular income for her family upkeep. She asserts that "cows have sustained my life and educated my kids".

A loan from Kiva will enable her to buy another dairy cow and hence increase her milk production. It will support her in living a better life from the increased income.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow to increase her milk sales

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
Construyendo el país de la eterna primavera y del desarrollo, Miguel de 35 años de edad casado con cinco hijos dos de ellos ya tienen familias separadas y los tres últimos son excelentes estudiantes en la escuela de su comunidad, los hijos  se a vuelto el más grande reto para el ya que tiene que hacer el esfuerzo de luchar por su familia cada día para darles un buen futuro y educación a sus hijos.

La actividad principal de el es la albañilería en la comunidad donde el vive, desde niño el tomo la decisión de aprender a construir casas de su comunidad dicha profesión a la venido trabajando desde hace 15 largos años de sacrificio pero que lo ha hecho con mucho orgullo parque lo hace por su familia porque necesitan de un ingreso económico para la satisfacción de las necesidades de su familia y para el desarrollo de su comunidad donde vive.

El propósito del crédito que el desea realizar es para la compra de herramientas de construcción en la albañilería ya que es de importancia para el y sin esas herramientas el no podrá trabajar para seguir construyendo en su comunidad.

Uno de los más grandes sueños de Miguel es ver crecer a sus hijos y darles educación para que llegue a ser unos profesionales y poner una constructora para el servicio de su comunidad y el desarrollo en un futuro.
texts.en:
Building the country of eternal spring and development, 35-year-old Miguel is married with five children. Two of them already have families of their own, and the three younger children are excellent students in the community school. The children have become his biggest challenge, as he must put all his effort into struggling every day to give his family a good future and educate his children.

Miguel's main activity is construction in the community where he lives. When he was a boy, he decided to learn how to build houses in his community. He has been working in that profession for 15 long years of sacrifice, but he has done it with great pride; he does it for his family because they need an income to satisfy their needs, and for the development of the community where he lives.

The desired purpose of this loan is the purchase of masonry construction tools. This is very important for him; without these tools, he won't be able to work to continue building in his community.

One of Miguel's greatest dreams is to see his children grow and to give them an education so that they can become professionals, and to set up a construction company to serve his community and its future development.

loans.use: to buy masonry construction tools.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
This is Lilian. She is a onion trader in Kisumu, Kenya. She dropped out of school after primary education since her mother could not raise school fees for her high school. Her single mother was struggling to provide for her and her siblings hence her early entry to business. Her initial capital was KES 5,000. She has managed to fully repay loans of KES 10,000, 20,000 and 40,000 which she received from the micro-finance institution ECLOF. 

Lilian has plans of expanding her business into wholesale. Her life has changed tremendously in that she is able to educate her children and pay school fees for her brother. She takes care of her aging mother. With support from Kiva, she will grow to a supplier of onions in the nearby markets.

loans.use: to buy more stock of onions

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
This is Martha. She was born in 1983, educated to secondary level education and rears dairy as her source of income. She currently owns one cow which is calved and producing milk for sale. Although her income is small she wants to increase her milk production to a level where she will realize her dream of owning a car. She is focused to continue growing her dairy herd to a level of producing enough milk that she will transport in her own car. 

A loan from Kiva will help Martha buy another cow; a major step towards realizing her dream.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow that will increase her milk production.

loans.name: Bibirukhsora

texts.ru:
Бибирухсоре 32 года. Она живет в районе Файзабад у своих родителей. У Бибирухсоры двое сыновей в возрасте 10 и 11 лет. Оба учатся в средней школе. Бибирухсора воспитывает и обеспечивает детей без мужа. Она работает в Штабе по чрезвычайным происшествиям и гражданской обороне своего района в течение 4 лет. Бибирухсора отзывчивая и ответственная женщина. Она любит свою работу. 
В данный момент Бибирухсора хочет провести ремонт в доме, однако ей еще не хватает немного денег, чтобы закупить материалы. Для этой цели она обратилась за кредитом. Она обещает выплачивать кредит в срок за счет своей работы. Бибирухсора надеется на вашу поддержку, так как хочет создать хорошие условия для житья.
texts.en: Bibirukhsora is 32 years old. She lives in the Fayzabad district with her parents. Bibirukhsora has two sons, who are 10 and 11 years old. Both of them attend a secondary school. Bibirukhsora is raising and providing for her children without a husband. She has been working at the Ministry for emergencies and civil defense in her district for 4 years. Bibirukhsora is a responsive and responsible woman. She loves her work. At the present time, Bibirukhsora wants to make repairs at home, but does not have enough money to buy materials. She requested a loan to achieve this goal. She promises to repay the loan on-time with the income from her job. Bibirukhsora hopes for your support because she wants to create good living conditions.

loans.use: to make repairs at home in order to create good living conditions

loans.name: Angela Maria

texts.es: La venta de mercancía mediante guías especializadas de productos o catálogos, es la actividad en la que se desempeña Angela, una joven de 23 años, que habita en un municipio del departamento del Atlántico, con su cónyuge y su pequeño hijo de 4 años de edad. Desde hace dos años inició su negocio pues estando muy pequeña ya su inclinación se hizo evidente. Fue así como con sus ahorros inició su negocio vendiendo a sus compañeras de trabajo de la empresa donde aun se encuentra vinculada. Hoy sus principales artículos son la ropa masculina, femenina la perfume ria que ofrece de manera directa a crédito a sus vecinos que son sus principales compradores, y a ellos les otorga crédito, que poco a poco pagan, con cuotas ajustada a sus posibilidades de respuesta. En la actualidad Angela está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa perfumería, accesorios femeninos y para el hogar en un mayor volumen, preparándose para atender la demanda de fin de año, temporada donde la ventas se incrementan y con ello puede lograr sus metas metas de mejorar sus ingresos y así mismo su calidad de vida, en tanto a que su mayor desafió es encontrar fuentes de financiación y con esta de Kiva lograda, empezará su ascenso al éxito.
texts.en:
Merchandise sales through specialized product guides or catalogues is the activity in which Angela, a 23-year-old young woman, is engaged.

She lives in a municipality in the department of Atlántico, with her husband and her 4-year-old son. 

She started her business two years ago, as her natural ability was already evident from a very young age. That was how, with her savings, she began her business selling to her work colleagues in the company where she still has links. 

Today her main items are menswear, women's clothing and perfume which she offers directly on credit terms to her neighbours who are her main buyers. She provides them with credit which they pay off gradually in instalments tailored to their ability to pay. 

Angela is currently applying for a Kiva loan, the first financing which she has requested from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With this, she will buy clothes, perfume, women's accessories and home accessories in a larger volume, preparing to meet the end of year demand, a season when sales increase. 

With this, she can achieve her goals to improve her income and thus her quality of life. In this, her biggest challenge is finding funding sources and with the granting of Kiva's loan, she will begin her rise to success.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfumes, women´s accessories and home accessories in larger volume

loans.name: Chelibeth Massiel

texts.es: Chelibeth tiene 20 años de edad, esta soltera y cursa el cuarto año de la carrera de Odontología en la universidad nacional autónoma de Nicaragua. Escogió esta carrera porque le gusta mucho y le apasiona ayudar a las personas que lo necesitan. Cuenta con el apoyo de su abuelita que tiene un taller de costura y le ayuda con los gastos relacionados a sus estudios así lograr terminar la carrera y ser una odontóloga reconocida en Nicaragua. Requiere el préstamo para comprar instrumentos de odontología tales como: Pinzas y tijeras. El préstamo le será de mucha ayuda ya que podrá realizar sus prácticas profesionales y poder desempeñarse de la mejor manera. Su meta próxima es terminar su carrera y su plan futuro es establecer su propia clínica.
texts.en:
Chelibeth is 20 years old. She is single and in her fourth year of the Dentistry program at the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Nicaragua [National Autonomous University of Nicaragua]. 

She chose this degree because she really likes and is inspired by helping people in need. She has the support of her grandmother, who has a sewing workshop and helps her with expenses related to her education so that she can finish her degree and be a well-known dentist in Nicaragua. 

Chelibeth needs the loan to buy dental instruments like tweezers and scissors. The loan will be very helpful since she will be able to do her professional internships and perform as well as possible. 

Her next goal is to finish her degree and her future plan is to establish her own clinic.

loans.use: to buy dentistry tools such as tweezers and scissors

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
This is Monica. She resides and conducts her business in Kisumu, Kenya. She started selling onions in 1993 after her first business of selling grocery gave her capital to expand. Her business skills were developed from her mother who exposed her to business when she was very young. She helped her mother run the family business during the holidays. The skills learnt have helped her grow her business from a very small business to the current state where she is able to sell in wholesale. 

Her dream is to become a regional supplier with her own transport vehicles. She will then provide employment to more workers. The business has assisted her educate two of her children up to university level. With a loan from Kiva, Monica will expand her business to make more sales and prepare for her next level of supplies.

loans.use: to buy and transport more onions to the market

loans.name: Alexander

texts.ru:
Александр 10 лет занимается тепличным хозяйством в селе Кардашинка. На 50 сотках в теплицах выращивает ранние и поздние помидоры и огурцы.

Предыдущий кредит помог Александру закупить необходимые семена, пленку и дрова для теплицы. Он успешно провел фермерский сезон и смог получить хорошую прибыль.

В этот раз Александр просит предоставить ему кредит в сумме 40 000 гривен на закупку удобрений, пленки и семян. Дополнительную прибыль он надеется вложить в развитие бизнеса.
texts.en:
Alexander has been involved in greenhouse farming in the Kardashinka village for 10 years. He grows early and late tomatoes and cucumbers in greenhouses on 50 ares of land. 

The previous loan helped Alexander to buy necessary seeds, plastic and firewood for a greenhouse. He successfully completed the farming season and was able to make a good profit. This time, Alexander is requesting a loan in the amount of 40 000 hryvnia to buy fertilizers, plastic and seeds. He is planning to invest the additional profit into developing his business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, plastic and seeds

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Alice. She is a single mother with two children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 and, after undergoing training in enterprise management, she can effectively manage her enterprise.
 
Alice practices maize, bean, and potato farming. She sells her produce in the local markets. Her goal is to expand her farming activities. It is for this reason that Alice is borrowing a loan to buy farm inputs, such as fertilizer and pesticide. 

Alice looks forward to a bountiful harvest. This will enable her to put up with the ever-rising demand for her produce, making her level of income increase. She plans to use her profits in pay school fees and to buy food for her children.

 Alice is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to promptly repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pestcide.

loans.name: Gulshaiyr

texts.ru: Гулшайыр 41 год, замужем, воспитывает 4 детей. Гулшайыр имеет среднее образование, много лет проработала на почте, по характеру она спокойный и общительный человек. Гулшайыр, в поисках дополнительного источника дохода, в 2001 году начала заниматься разведением скота и полеводством. Гулшайыр приложила все усилия для развития своего бизнеса, на сегодняшний день в хозяйстве есть 1 корова, 1 теленок, 40 овец, 7 коз и 2 лошади. Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гулшайыр обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 90,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 2 лошадей. В будущем, Гулшайыр планирует расширить свою деятельность и купить земельный участок в городе.
texts.en: Gulshaiyr is 41 years old, married and raising 4 children. Gulshaiyr has a secondary education and has been working at a post office for many years. She is a calm and sociable person. In search for an additional source of income, she got involved in raising livestock and farming in 2001. Gulshaiyr put forth all of her efforts to develop her business and today has 1 cow, 1 calf, 40 sheep, 7 goats and 2 horses. In order to further develop her business, Gulshaiyr requested a loan in the amount of 90,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy 2 horses. In the future, Gulshaiyr is planning to expand her business and buy a land plot in the city.

loans.use: to buy two horses in order to grow her business and income

loans.name: Iginio

texts.es: Iginio es un joven de 36 años de edad, el es de nacionalidad colombiana y se vino de ese país hacia Ecuador en busca de trabajo y de una vida más estable y segura,  ya que comenta que en Colombia hay demasiada inseguridad ya que la guerrilla secuestra y asesina a las personas inocentes, Iginio agradece por el crédito que se le otorga y comenta que lo va a invertir en la  compra de vaconas para seguir con esta actividad que lleva más de un año realizando, Iginio se dedica a trabajar en el campo como peón de sus patrones, Iginio espera quedarse en Ecuador y  seguir trabajando para tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Iginio is a young 36-year-old man. He is Colombian and came to Ecuador in search of work and a more stable and secure life, since in Colombia he says there is great insecurity; there are guerrilla kidnappings and assassinations of innocent people.
Iginio is grateful for this loan and says that he will invest in the purchase of cows to continue with his business. He has had the business for over a year. Iginio works in the field as a labourer. He hopes to stay in Ecuador and to continue working in order to have a greater quality of life.

loans.use: to buy cows

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: La fabricación de mecedoras cromadas y barandas hospitalarias, es el negocio de Pedro, un joven de 19 años de edad, quien aprovechó el conocimiento de su padre, quien trabajaba en una empresa que producía mecedoras cromadas y le enseñó a Pedro todo lo que hoy sabe. Cuando llegó a su mayoría de edad, hace 2 años, decidió generar sus propios ingresos con el conocimiento aprendido de su padre. Hoy su principal clientela la constituyen, sus vecinos y empresas a quienes les vende de contado. Su mayor desafió es lograr la suficiente solvencia económica para poder ampliar su empresa y aumentar sus ganancias. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará taladros y otros activos fijos así como materiales de trabajo. Con esta inversión disminuiría los costos de los materiales y le ayudaría mucho en su competitividad también por la baja tasa de intereses, con las que adquirió su credikiva.
texts.en: Pedro's business involves making chrome plated and wooden hospital rocking chairs.  He is 19 years old and learned this work from his father, who used to work for a company that produced chrome plated rocking chairs.  He taught Pedro everything he knew.  When Pedro became an adult, two years ago, he decided to generate his own income with the knowledge gained from his father.  Today his principal clientele is made up of neighbors and business who he sells to for cash.  His greatest challenge is gaining enough economic stability to be able to grow his business and to increase his income.  Currently he is applying for a loan from Kiva, the first loan that he is requesting through Kiva partner Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  He will use it to buy drills and other tools and materials for his work.  This loan will decrease the cost of materials and will make his work more competitive, as well as keep him from paying higher interest rates.

loans.use: To purchase drills and other tools for his rocking chair business.

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir, 35, is a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. He is married to Marianne, a teacher, and has one child who is in preparatory school. He and his wife work together to provide income to meet their family’s daily personal and household needs.

Vladimir is a proprietor of a retail general store. In the Philippines, a general store store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry and packaged commodities.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. He earns a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. His store is located adjacent to his house. Vladimir has a charming personality and people prefer to buy at his store. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of PHP 1,200 in sales every day. 

To help him continue operation of his business, Vladimir is requesting a PHP 40,000 loan to buy grocery items such as sacks of rice, corn, charcoal, sugar, cooking oil, and beverages. He also retails prepaid loads of mobile phones. He is positive this will boost his income as he expands his business. He is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given him.

Vladimir aims to grow his business to give his family a bright future. He wants to give his child the best education possible. He prays to be victorious and lead a Godly life. He faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items and pre-paid loads (mobile phone) to sell at retail.

loans.name: Joash

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is called Joash. He is fifty-three years old, married, and blessed with three children.

Joash practices dairy farming. The training he got from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa has enabled him run his enterprise effectively.

He is applying for a loan to enable him achieve his goal of expanding his business. With the loan, he will buy more calves to raise, which will, in the long run, increase the amount of milk produced. He plans to use the profits to support his children's education.

Joash is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy calves.

loans.name: Irma Del Carmen

texts.es:
Irma tiene 60 años de edad, estudió los primeros años de bachillerato, luego contrajo matrimonio, está felizmente casada y su esposo se dedica al cultivo del maíz, tiene siete hijos, de los cuales solo 3 viven con ellos.

Irma tiene dos molinos con los cuales obtienen ingresos cuando las personas llegan a moler maíz, el molino se encuentra ubicado en las cercanías de la ciudad en una casa que su esposo compró, sus hijos se involucran en el trabajo.

Ella necesita el crédito para mejorar las condiciones del molino, específicamente pondrá piso ya que es de tierra, además comprará algunas piezas del molino que están deterioradas como fajas, discos, arandelas, etc.

Ella sueña con que su negocio vaya prosperando y así gozar de buenos ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Irma is 60 years old. She completed the first years of High School, after that, she got married.
She is happily married, and her husband grows corn. They have 7 children, 3 of whom still live with them. 


Irma has two mills, and she gets an income from the people who go there to mill the corn. The mill is located next to the city, in a house purchased by her husband. Her kids get involved in the job. 

She needs the loan to improve the conditions of the mill, specifically she wants to install the floor, because right now it is just dirt, and she also wants to buy some pieces that are damaged, such as belts, discs, washers, etc.

Her dream is to have a prosperous business and to get a good income.

loans.use: to improve the conditions of the mill.

loans.name: Cherlita

texts.en:
Cherlita is 42 years old and married with four children.

Cherlita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 24,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional merchandise like sardines, soft drinks, noodles, etc. to sell.

Cherlita has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.

Cherlita aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise like sardines, soft drinks, noodles, etc. to sell

loans.name: Pablo Mesias

texts.es: Pablo es un señor de 35 años,  vive con sus padres, hermanos y sobrinos, en una casa muy humilde, Pablo se dedica al jornal de trabajo en el campo y también a la crianza de terneros, comenta este señor que su negocio de comprar ganado lo inició desde que una vez se gano un ternero en una rifa de la localidad y desde ahí le va bien en este negocio aunque tiene que pagar arriendo para la hierba, Pablo va a invertir el crédito en la compra de terneros para tenerlos juntos con su ternerito de a suerte como él lo llama , lo que Pablo aspira es seguir comprando mas toretes y comercializarlos , incrementar su  negocio y de esta forma seguir ayudando en los gastos del hogar y salud de sus padres ya que lo necesitan porque ya son muy viejitos.
texts.en:
Pablo is a 35-year-old man who lives with his parents, siblings and cousins in a very humble house. Pablo is a rural day laborer and also raises calves. He comments that his cattle buying business began after he won some land in a local raffle. Since then, he has done well in the business, even though he must pay rent for grazing land. 

Pablo will invest the loan in purchasing calves to add to his “good luck flock,” as he calls them. What Pablo aspires to is to continue buying more young bulls and to sell them, expanding his business and, in this form, to continue helping with household expenses and the cost of his parents' health care, which they need because they are now very old.

loans.use: buy calves to raise.

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
A married parent of five children, Cherry works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling rice in the Philippines and earns additional income from farming rice.

Cherry is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell through her buy-and-sell rice business.

Cherry has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Myrsagyz

texts.ru: Мырсагыз 55 лет, замужем, есть 3 детей, младший сын живет с родителями. У Мырсагыз средне-специальное образование, она товаровед. В качестве дополнительного источника дохода для семьи, Мырсагыз уже много лет занимается животноводством и полеводством. Ее хозяйство, на сегодня приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. На данный момент в хозяйстве Мырсагыз имеется 2 дойные коровы, 2 бычка и 20 овец. Также на земельном наделе мерою 2,40 Га она выращивает фасоль и многолетние травы. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Мырсагыз обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 20 овец. Доходы Мырсагыз планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота.
texts.en:
Myrsagyz is 55 and married with three children. Only their youngest son still lives with them. She has a specialist high school education and is a product distribution manager. She also has been working in animal husbandry and agriculture for many years as an additional source of income for her family. Her farm now brings in about 10,000 KGS per month thanks to her two dairy cows, two steers and 20 sheep, as well as 2.4 hectares of land where she grows beans and hay.

With the goal of further developing her business, Myrsagyz has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase 20 sheep. She plans to put profits from the loan into further increasing her number of livestock.

loans.use: to buy 20 sheep for fattening and resale in order to to invest in her business

loans.name: Somkid

texts.en:
Somkid has worked hard to overcome the obstacles he's faced- for the traditional Mlabri who were raised in a hunting and gathering lifestyle, there has been huge upheaval in their lifetime. When their lands were destroyed by guerrilla warfare and teak harvesting, the Mlabri were left without options. Most, including Somkid, became trapped in a cycle of debt slavery as field laborers. 

Hammock weaving was the first opportunity that helped Somkid change his circumstances. Being illiterate in today's world has been a challenge for him, not to mention the detailed measurements, numbers and patterns that weavers must master! As he puts it, “None of that matters too much in the jungle.” 

But Somkid has done well for himself- he earns a stable living, maintains his traditional values and he's kept his fun-loving spirit. He is a great story-teller and he's making sure that Mlabri history and stories are still being passed down. He is married to Yalana and he is going to use his Kiva loan to make improvements to their house so that they have a more comfortable, secure place to weave and live.

loans.use: to make improvements to his workspace to have a more comfortable, secure place to make hammocks.

loans.name: Tadi

texts.en:
Tadi was born in the jungles to a traditional Mlabri family. His father and mother were still nomadic hunters and gatherers when he was born.  It was during his lifetime that slash and burn agriculture destroyed the forest to such an extent that the Mlabri had no option except to drastically change their lifestyle. He spent many years working as a field laborer before the hammock project began.

Tadi has seen many changes in his lifetime and he feels like one of the few "bridges" between the old way of life and the integrated younger generation. Today, he supports his family by growing rice and weaving hammocks. He also holds a fascinating role as a language helper for University Professors studying the Mlabri language and culture. To this day, he will go out hunting in what's left of the jungle at the drop of a hat! For him, hunting is his connection to the traditional world he was born in. 

Tadi takes pride in weaving alongside his wife Yadi and appreciates the security that their shared weaving work offers. They have six children, so this loan will help them spread their weaving work across the calendar year and ensure their kids can focus on school -- creating new opportunity for the next generation.

loans.use: to increase his overall production capacity and secure long term weaving work.

loans.name: Chow

texts.en:
Chow is part of the new generation of her tribe, the Mlabri. While many of the elders in her village were born in the jungles to a traditional hunter and gatherer lifestyle, Chow was born during a time of transition. The Mlabri were at a crossroads, where the hunting and gathering lifestyle was no longer an option. The adults were struggling to overcome exploitation (as indentured field laborers and tourist attractions) and to find a new path to independence. 

In the village where Chow grew up, the Mlabri were turned into a tourist stop. Unethical wranglers would promise Western tourists a look at “authentic” and “primitive” hill tribe life. They would force the Mlabri to don loincloths and act out traditional rituals in the forest, then pay them with a small amount of food instead of sharing the tourist’s payment. 

Because of this upbringing, Chow was very shy- but she can stand up for herself! She moved with her husband to the Ban Boonyuen village and was determined to learn to weave hammocks and earn a solid income through her own skills. Now she has one child and she is determined to build a stable life, make sure her children receive an education and see that her family is not vulnerable to exploitation ever again. This loan will help them work on hammocks during the slow season, so that they can build their savings and security!

loans.use: to increase her overall production capacity and secure long term weaving work.

loans.name: Udom

texts.en:
Udom has had a tumultuous life. His mother, Sukanya, was born in the jungles when their tribe was still able to hunt and gather. But the forests were destroyed, his father left their family and Sukanya had to raise six children on the meager income of an indentured field laborer. 

Perhaps because of this tough background, Udom has always been a hard worker. He is a member of the newer generation in his village and learned to read, write and speak Thai. His mother’s weaving work made it possible for him to attend school, where he was dedicated to his studies. Despite his Thai education, he remains loyal to the Mlabri Tribe and is committed to continuing Mlabri traditions.

His wife, Chow, is also a weaver. They recently had their first child and he is committed to building a stable life for his family. He originally wanted to be an independent farmer, but he sees the value of the secure income that is possible for weavers. Through this loan, he and Chow will build their nest egg and begin to save for the future. Hopefully one day he will have his own farm too!

loans.use: to increase production capacity and secure consistent weaving work.

loans.name: Plaa

texts.en:
After rampant environmental destruction drove the Mlabri Tribe from their traditional forest home, Plaa and her family were forced into bondage as field laborers in back-breaking toxic agriculture. Exploited, impoverished and malnourished, only 300 Mlabri survived this dark era.

Now Plaa's life has changed tremendously - she is proud to say that her weaving skills feeds her family. She is leading them to a brighter future through her talent and hard work. 

Plaa has been weaving for her whole life! Before the hammock project began, she was an expert in the art of weaving traditional Mlabri bags, which were used in the tribe's hunting & gathering and helped inspire the idea to weave hammocks. Among the tribe, she is recognized as the very best weaver and she is an especially great teacher. She and her husband Taton have 9 children and they support their large family with their income from hammocks. This loan will help them get ahead of weaving cycles and permanently break the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: to increase her overall production capacity and secure long term weaving work.

loans.name: Ardiana

texts.en:
Ardiana is 44 years old and has three children.  She is married and has children who are in school.

She is in an agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Ardiana requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins.

Ardiana has been raising pigs for 14 years now, and has borrowed 21 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.  In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Editha works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Editha is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase sacks of rice to sell in her rice retailing business.

Editha has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 29 years old and married with one child.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling plastic wares in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of plastic wares to sell.

Jocelyn has borrowed and repaid 3 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the business buying and selling plastic wares for 5 years and also earns an income from a general store.  Jocelyn aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of plastic wares to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 50 years old, married, and has four children, two of whom are in school.  

She is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Jocelyn requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more feed and pay her laborers' salaries.

Jocelyn has been raising pigs for 13 years now, and has borrowed 21 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Jocelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more feed and pay her laborers' salaries

loans.name: Mylen

texts.en:
Mylen, 42 years old, is married and has five children, two of them in school. For the past 11 years, Mylen has operated an agricultural business farming rice in the Philippines. 

Mylen has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies. She has previously borrowed 14 times from NWTF to sustain her business. In the future, Mylen would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's financial stability.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Tita

texts.en: Tita, 35 years old, is married and has one child who is in school. She works very hard to provide for her family. For the past 10 years, Tita has run a general store in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy items such as shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell. In the future, Tita would like to save money to expand her business.
